1    Hazardous Material Release and Control 

1.1    LNG - LNG Storage Area

LNG is a cryogenic liquid which will damage material it contacts which are not designed for the extreme cold temperatures. This includes carbon steel, rubber and skin tissue. The LNG will vaporize and the resulting flammable gas will rise and dissipate. The key items in an LNG release are to protect personnel and materials from contacting the LNG, shut off the source of the release, contain the liquid until dissipated, and eliminate any ignition sources in the area of the vapor.



A small leak of LNG spraying on a carbon steel pipe or vessel can cause it to crack. Placing cardboard, plywood, or some other material between the spray and the material can protect it until the leak is stopped A small leak of LNG can be successfully slopped by covering the area with wet rags which will freeze forming a solid ice plug.



The storage area has a detention basin designed to hold total volume plus 10% of the main LNG storage tank. The area is slopped to ensure any release of LNG drains into the detention basin. The sump contains a low temperature detection element which activates the, hazard alarm and deactivates the sump pump to ensure containment.



DO NOT spray water onto the liquid LNG as this will significantly increase the vapor generation rate. If the vapor generation rate needs to be slowed or if the vapors have ignited, use dry chemical fire extinguishing media on the LNG surface.

1.2    LNG - Truck Area Spill

The hazards are the same except that the location is outside the storage dike area. The key actions remain the same. The most likely cause for a spill is a busted or accidental disconnection of a loading hose at either the truck loading or fueling station. Several safeguards exist including gas detectors, low temperature sump detectors, an automatic fueling shutoff upon disconnecting the fuel nozzle, and a truck loading ESD activated either locally or remotely.



A spill would be directed

by area drainage to a sump located away from either the truck loading or fueling stations. The sump is large enough to hold an entire trailer contents.

1.3    Sulfuric Acid Spill

A 300 gallon sulfuric acid tank is located inside a contained vessel near the cooling tower. The vessel can contain the contents of the tank. Sulfuric acid is a corrosive material and can cause skin tissue damage. Avoid breathing vapors from the acid. The acid is not capable of supporting combustion. The reportable quantity limit for sulfuric acid released outside the vessel is 1000 pounds. The acid contained inside the vessel must be either returned to storage or neutralized and disposed of properly.



Material outside the dike must be contained in the drainage system to prevent discharge off the property. This can be done with sand bags or an earthen dike. The material must then be neutralized and disposed of properly.

1.4    Amine Spill

The amine units are also inside dike areas which can contain leaks from equipment. The amine is also considered corrosive requiring personnel protective equipment. The reportable quantity limit for the amine is 1000 pounds. Any spill must be contained, collected and disposed of properly.

1.5    Sodium Hypochlorite Spill

This material, also known as liquid chlorine, is used in the cooling water system to prevent bacterial organisms from thriving causing problems such as algae in the water. This material is kept in 500 gallon drums inside the dike near the cooling tower. One drum is kept at the potable water well. A spill outside of a dike would cause high residual chlorine levels in the discharge water. To contain and collect this material, use sand bags or an earthen dike. The reportable quantity limit is 100 pounds.

1.6    Oil Spill

Oil is used in rotating equipment for lubrication. Any leak must be immediately cleaned up. The use of rags and absorbent material is acceptable as long as the materials are properly disposed of. Any oil in the water drainage m

ust be contained and collected for disposal.

1.7    Refrigerant Gas Release

The refrigerant is a R134A. A release of the refrigerant is a significant fire hazard since the gas would be heavier than air and therefore would not dissipate quickly. The gas could travel along the ground to an ignition source and flash back to the point of release.



Gas detectors are located throughout the plant which alarm at a concentration of 20% LEL and again at 40% LEL. At the latter alarm, a shutdown timer of 2 minutes starts. If the situation is not cleared and the alarm resets in that period or the operator intervenes, an automatic shutdown of the affected area will occur.

1.8    Natural Gas Release

The natural gas feed to the plant via pipeline is at about 800 psig. The natural gas is primarily methane and is colorless and odorless. A gas detector alarm should be immediately investigated. Due to the high pressure, caution should be used in trying to find a leak to avoid bodily injury. 



In the event of a release, the feed can be shutdown remotely. If the natural gas ignites, shut off the feed and allow the fire to burn itself out, if it doesn't threaten the health and safety of individuals and/or property damage.

4    Responding to Emergencies

4.1    Response to emergencies

Emergency situations and events will vary widely and require various levels of management to direct the handling of the emergency and subsequent restoration of operations and reporting.

4.2    Examples of possible emergencies

The following are examples of situations that could result in emergencies throughout the Clean Energy service area:

?A    Event or fire that involves or threatens the LNG facility.

?A    Uncontrolled escape of LNG.

?A    LNG pressure that is outside prescribed limits.

?A    Damage to our facilities by third parties.

?A    Civil disturbance that can result in damage to the facility.

4.3    Dispatching emergency personnel

In response to a notice of a possible emergency, a plant operator may be dispatched to the location. As each emergency is unique in nature, they should follow the key guidelines outlined in the "Emergency Response Procedures" with the mindset to prevent bodily injury first, and then make the area safe and secure. The situation at hand will dictate the order of how plant personnel may execute the guidelines. 

4.4    Immediate on-site action

Upon arrival at the site, the first responder shall assess the nature of the emergency and determine if it is LNG related. This assessment should include the status of the emergency, an estimation of how the incident might progress, and an evaluation of whether or not additional manpower, equipment, and materials are needed to adequately cope with the situation. 



 

5    Incident Commander System (ICS)

5.1    Incident Commander

The ranking company employee at the scene will be designated the Incident Commander. The Incident Commander is responsible for directing and coordinating the overall emergency response. To help insure coordination during the emergency, the Incident Commander will normally appoint specific persons to perform specific tasks. Incident Commander should make a written record of the persons assigned to various tasks. This will help define the temporary chain of command that will be used during the emergency.

In all emergencies requiring the assistance of external emergency response agencies, the Incident Commander position shall be turned over to the applicable emergency response agency upon arrival t

o the site. 

5.1.1    Emergency Command Center (EOC)

The control room will serve as the EOC. This room is equipped with:

?Q    A set of P&ID's and plans illustrating system components and safety features.

?Q    Remote shutdown capabilities

?Q    Control of all plant cameras

?Q    Control of main front gate

?Q    LAN Telephone

?Q    Plant Radios

?Q    Plant Paging System

?Q    Direct access to the motor control panel

5.1.2    Fire Department (Roles & Responsibilities)

If an emergency requires the assistance of the local fire department, regardless if fire related, the Incident Commander position will be assumed by the Senior Ranking Officer of the fire department, upon their arrival. The Senior Ranking Officer shall command the emergency response and resuce efforts. A Clean Energy employee should remain with the Senior Ranking Officer to provide knowledge and guidance about the site to aid the Fire Department with the response effort. 

5.1.3    Police Department (Roles & Responsibilities)

The Police Department is responsible for controlling the movement of traffic, evacuation efforts (when necessary), protection of personnel and securing the vicinity of the emergency. 



If the incident was a result of a deliberate act amounting to criminal conduct, the law enforcement agency having jurisdiction should perform a thorough and detailed investigation.

 

5.2    First Responder

The primary role of the first responder is to evaluate the situation and notify the appropriate Company and/or emergency response personnel. Once the situation has been assessed, the First Responder should attempt to make the situation safe and communicate actions with the Incident Commander.



Clean Energy First Responders shall always provide for the own safety above all duties. The First Responder should assume the role of Incident Commander until Management arrives.

5.3    Public Information and Media Relations

In the event of an emergency, it is critical that information released to public agencies, the m

edia, and ultimately the general public be accurate. Clean Energy's Public Relations Manager will be responsible to maintain good public relations in the community involved. Please review the "Media Relations" section of this plan for more information. 

5.4    Emergency Communication

The following are means of communicating among personnel within the LNG Plant.

5.4.1    Plant Alarms

The plant has two alarms sirens which sound on loud speakers throughout the facility. All employees are trained on the required actions of each alarm at the time of hire, during orientation or before initial assignment, procedural change or whenever there is reason to believe there is a lack of proper skill or comprehension



All site visitors and contractors are oriented on the alarms and their required actions upon initial arrival to the plant, prior to the beginning of work / business at the plant. 

5.4.2    Plant Paging System

The plant paging system includes a telephone style handset at the following locations:

?Q    Location 1:

?Q    Location 2:



Each handset has the capability of speaking to other handsets or having a message broadcast over the loud speakers throughout the plant.  This paging system will be used to supplement the alarm system to notify personnel within the plant of important information.

5.4.3    Plant Radios

Plant Personnel use portable radios to communicate from anywhere in the plant with the control room. During an emergency, radio traffic is limited to only information necessary for the response efforts. 

5.4.4    Mobile Telephones

All plant employees have cell phones. Plant employees may be contacted and communicate via mobile phone when needed. All employee telephone numbers are conspicuously posted in the control room and a copy is available in the Emergency Response Plan. 

6    COMMUNICATION PLAN

The communication plan is to serve as the priomary tool for implementing communication related activities to emergency situations, including communication within C

lean Energy and to external entities.

6.1    Initial Response and Notifications

An immediate emergency notification will be issued by the Incident Commander when a confirmation of a site emergency situation exists. The Incident Commander will, without delay, initiate emergency notification protocol, unless issuing a notification will, in the professional judgement of the Incident Commander, compromise efforts to assist a victim or to contain, respond to, or otherwise mitigate the emergency.

6.2    Clean Energy Emergency Notification 

Clean Energy has established a procedure for plant personnel to contact and notify key Clean Energy corporate managers and officers. Emergency communication shall be performed according to the flow illustrated in the Clean Energy Emergency Notification Flow Chart. 



The general procedure for communicating an emergency should be as follows, starting with:

1.    Communicate internally within the LNG Plant, then;

2.    Contact 911 if needed, then;

3.    Notify Clean Energy Corporate of situation, and then;

4.    Notify applicable external agencies and entities of the emergency

6.3    External Notification Agencies

The LNG Plant is required to notify external agencies according to the type of emergency. Communication and notification requirements to these entities are detailed in the "Emergency Response Procedures" section of the ERP.



7    INCIDENT INVESTIGATION SUMMARY - BORON HOT OIL TANK RELEASE 140317



    The Clean Energy Corporate Safety Manager received notification of an incident at the Boron plant on March 17, 2014 at approximately 08:00 from Plant Supervisor Tim Montalbano.  The incident involved a hot oil pump, which failed, and resulted in a release of DowTherm G Heat Transfer Fluid from a damaged valve.  The fluid sprayed from the damaged valve, coating the surrounding equipment and ground.  The total quantity released was initially estimated at 500 gallons, but was reduced to approximately 350 gallons based on the amount of fluid needed

to replenish the system after the incident.  



The ground area affected by the release is completely covered with rock, and the released fluid ran into several low-lying areas where it puddled.  The leak was eventually stopped, and the fluid on the ground contained.  The Clean Energy Corporate Safety Manager began making all the proper notifications and instructed Tim Montalbano to continue the cleanup operations while that took place (CHS Environmental was brought onsite on the day of the incident to begin and continue cleanup efforts, and Double Barrel Environmental was contracted to perform any soil remediation efforts that were required).



Kern County Environmental Health Services was notified first due to the original 500 gallon leak estimate (Kern County EHS is the authorizing agency for Cal/ARP).  The California Office of Emergency Services (OES) was notified second as a requirement for any potentially hazardous material spilled above the Reportable Quantity.  California OES assumed the responsibility of generating a report and making additional notifications to other outside agencies if required.  The Clean Energy Corporate Safety Manager followed up the initial notification with a written report to OES within 7 days of the incident.



The incident investigation shows the cause of the incident to be mechanical failure.
